title.narrative: Establishing infrastructure and capacity for the management of the Ngamikka Landscape

description.narrative: This project makes progress towards the establishment of a national park for the NgamikkaLuama landscape on the shores of Lake Tanganyika in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. This project will conserve the rich biodiversity of this landscape by addressing the impacts of road building, extractive industries, and bushmeat hunting. Specific activities include: 1) establishment of a landscape conservation plan, 2) improvement of management infrastructure and capacity, and 3) increasing awareness of protected area boundaries.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: USAID-Wildlife Security

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to protect endangered species in Uganda and eastern Democratic Republic of Congo from illegal wildlife trafficking. The project is intended to conserve great apes, elephants and other species by addressing the illegal hunting of great apes for meat, body parts and live infant pets and the slaughter of elephants for ivory through increasing the level of wildlife law enforcement and deterring potential traffickers from conducting these illegal activities. Specific activities include: 1) replication of the Last Great Ape Organization (LAGA) model for non-governmental organization (NGO) - government collaboration on wildlife law enforcement in Uganda and DRC, 2) setting a precedence of wildlife prosecution with a major wildlife criminal on trial in each country, 3) establishing sustainable national projects of wildlife law enforcement with a one arrest per week enforcement rate and creating a block of countries with functioning enforcement, and 4) establishing a model for sub-regional wildlife law enforcement using the model of investigations, arrest operations, legal assistance, media promotion and reporting. ."

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: African Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support elephant conservation in Murchison Falls National Park and other conservation areas in Uganda by expanding intelligence and operational capacity using WILD LEO technology. The project is intended to conserve elephants by addressing the impacts of poaching and problems faced by wildlife law enforcement. Specific activities include: 1) expansion of the use of geolocation cameras to gather detailed data to monitor elephant distributions, observe illegal activities, and create patrol deployment strategies in order to strengthen management, inform operational decisions and provide robust evidence for wildlife crime prosecution throughout the conservation areas in Uganda; and 2) establishment of management controls such as the construction of a ranger post in the Wangkwar Valley and the development of community partnerships and conservation education in local schools to increase understanding about elephant conservation and park management in the Nanda regions of Murchison Falls.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: The expansion of intelligence led elephant management and protection throughout Uganda

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support elephant conservation in Murchison Falls National Park and other conservation areas in Uganda by expanding intelligence and operational capacity using WILD LEO technology. The project is intended to conserve elephants by addressing the impacts of poaching and problems faced by wildlife law enforcement. Specific activities include: 1) expansion of the use of geolocation cameras to gather detailed data to monitor elephant distributions, observe illegal activities, and create patrol deployment strategies in order to strengthen management, inform operational decisions and provide robust evidence for wildlife crime prosecution throughout the conservation areas in Uganda; and 2) establishment of management controls such as the construction of a ranger post in the Wangkwar Valley and the development of community partnerships and conservation education in local schools to increase understanding about elephant conservation and park management in the Nanda regions of Murchison Falls.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Strengthening the Capacity of Uganda Wildlife Authority to tackle the Ivory trade

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to prevent ivory trafficking and transit through Uganda by building the capacity of Uganda Wildlife Authority's (UWA) newly formed Wildlife Crime Unit. The project is intended to conserve elephants by addressing poaching, illegal trade and transit. Specific activities include: 1) provision of training to selected UWA staff to be able to tackle illegal wildlife trafficking, assess management needs and establish a framework for reporting information from the field to headquarters, and development of a master plan for upgrading UWA operations to enhance law enforcement; and 2) improvement in monitoring and information management through training in new technologies and roll out of an offenders and crime database to better track poaching suspects and prosecutions of cases in Ugandan courts.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to reduce the risk of disease transmission between people and mountain gorillas by improving the health and hygiene of Batwa communities that neighbor Bwindi Impenetrable National Park, Uganda.

title.narrative: Protect Uganda largest elephant population by establishing monthly patrol planning with SMART data

description.narrative: This project will support anti-poaching efforts at two of Ugandas largest remaining elephant populations, Murchison Falls National Park and Queen Elizabeth National Park. Specific activities will include implementing and maintaining the SMART law enforcement monitoring system across both parks to better detect threats, to understand patterns in real-time, and to improve patrol coverage and effort.

title.narrative: Disruption of IWT networks by increasing the capacity of the judiciary and prosecutors through.training and technical support, and increasing cooperation among the different agents involved

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to disrupt IWT networks in Uganda by increasing the capacity of the judiciary and prosecutors through training and technical support, and increasing cooperation among the different agents involved in fighting wildlife crime. Specific objectives include: 1) research and collect precedent wildlife crime cases in Kenay and Tanzania; 2) update the Wildlife Crime Prosecution Manual and Guidelines for Uganda; 3) develop a new Wildlife Manual and Guidelines for magistrates and judges; and 4) train 60 selected prosecutors, magistrates and judges across Uganda.

title.narrative: Assessing Anthropogenic Threats to Endangered Mountain Gorillas in Bwindi Impenetrable National Park, Uganda

description.narrative: : 1) continuing long-term monitoring of group size, structure, and birth and mortality rates of habituated groups; 2) quantifying the time habituated gorilla groups spend outside of the park, and spend crop raiding; 3) quantifying the frequency of habituated gorilla groups crossing the park road; 4) strengthening national capacity for science-based conservation and tourism management; and 5) conducting conservation education and community outreach.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Developing an Evidence-Based Approach to Change Behaviors of Chinese Buying Elephant Ivory in Africa

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to counter wildlife trafficking in Uganda by reducing the volume of ivory purchased by Chinese travelers living in or visiting the country. This project is intended to conserve African elephants by understanding and tackling illegal ivory trade in a major source and transit country, thereby reducing poaching pressure on the species. The project design includes a two-pronged approach that focuses on (1) improving understanding of the illegal ivory market in Uganda, and (2) developing an evidence-based behavior change framework targeting Chinese travelers to Uganda. Specific activities will include: (1) Monitor and analyze characteristics of key markets that sell ivory in Uganda; (2) conduct qualitative research to understand Chinese ivory buyers in Ugandan markets; (3) conduct demographic research on staff, affiliates and visitors of Chinese SOEs in Uganda to identify high risk demographic groups of Chinese travelers; (4) undertake knowledge, awareness and perception surveys on ivory and elephant conservation in focus groups from Chinese SOEs; (5) design wildlife trafficking mitigation framework with targeted Chinese SOEs to reduce the number of Chinese travelers engaged in ivory trade; and (6) conduct consultation meetings in Uganda and Beijing with key community leaders, diplomatic representatives, corporations and influential media.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Monitoring and Mitigating Anthropogenic Threats to Critically Endangered Mountain Gorillas in Bwindi Impenetrable National Park, Uganda

description.narrative: The purpose of this 1-year project is to investigate potential anthropogenic effects on mountain gorillas of Bwindi Impenetrable National Park through the long-term study of gorilla population dynamics and feeding ecology. Activities include: 1) monitoring group size, structure, behaviors, time spent outside of the park, frequency of crossing the Ruhija road, and of crop-raiding in farms; 2) training Uganda Wildlife Authority personnel on gorilla demography database management, gorilla biology, and tourism guidelines and regulations; 3) improving local understanding of, and support for, conservation by engaging primary school children in classroom instruction, community clean-ups, forest walks, and developing tree nurseries; 5) strengthening education through teacher training workshops; and 6) improving community support for gorilla conservation, and reduce illegal harvesting of park resources, through film screenings and engaging discussions.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: Securing Forest Connectivity for Chimpanzees in Uganda's Albertine Rift

description.narrative: The purpose of this 2-year project is to maintain and restore connectivity between key fragmented chimpanzee forest habitats in the northern Albertine Rift of Uganda by creating direct incentives for communities. Activities include: 1) supporting at least 80 households to maintain, strengthen, and enhance their mobile phone-based chimpanzee monitoring network; 2) engaging at least 40 community members in piloting chimpanzee threat monitoring in the corridors; 3) increasing local stakeholders awareness and understanding of the biodiversity value of the corridors; 4) supporting at least 20 farmers to maintain the initial 30 ha of forest proximal land on their farms; 5) supporting at least 20 additional farmers to implement a pilot reforestation of at least 30 ha of degraded habitat; 6) piloting Microloan Scheme Phase 1 (Village Savings and Loan Association (VLSA)) to create livelihood-based incentives for forest conservation and stewardship for at least 62 households; 7) piloting Microloan Scheme Phase 2 (Revolving Fund) to create livelihood-based incentives for forest conservation and stewardship for at least 90% of targeted households; and 8) strengthening and empowering local governance to ensure the microloan program results in conservation and livelihood impacts.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: Sterngthening Enforcement Against the Illegal Pangolin and Hippopotamus Trafficking in Uganda

description.narrative: This project will counter wildlife trafficking of key species in Uganda including pangolins, hippopotamus, and okapi. Pangolins are poached for their scales (to supply the demand in Asia) and meat, which is offered in many Chinese-owned restaurants serving Ugandas growing Asian population. Hippopotamus teeth or ivory are sought as a less expensive, lower risk alternative to elephant ivory. Okapis are locally extinct in Uganda but are increasingly found in seizures, indicating a transboundary trade between Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo. The Natural Resource Conservation Network is the only non-governmental entity in Uganda with the mandate to prosecute wildlife crimes. This two-year grant will support: a data entry officer to manage historic and ongoing wildlife crime data; development of an improved data collection and management system, including a system to map criminal networks; a data analyst to compile and analyze data on wildlife trafficking networks; targeted field investigations and prosecutions of wildlife traffickers; coalition-building and information sharing with local and international enforcement authorities to address transboundary trafficking networks; secure storage of confidential information related to wildlife cases; workshops with relevant authorities on changes to wildlife laws; and media outreach to raise awareness of the impacts of wildlife trafficking.

title.narrative: Restoring forest connectivity in Uganda's Albertine Rift for chimpanzee conservation

description.narrative: The purpose of this 1-year project is to enhance the viability of Uganda's eastern chimpanzee populations by maintaining and restoring connectivity between forests in the northern Albertine Rift. Specific activities include: 1) establishing a robust and effective community-based chimpanzee monitoring program; 2) extend reforestation/afforestation to two critical linkages between forest reserves; and 3) using conservation agriculture, REDD+, environmental education, and small enterprise support to garner greater focus from the Northern Albertine Rift Conservation Group on the target areas.

title.narrative: ADDRESSING HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT INVOLVING EASTERN CHIMPANZEES (PAN TROGLODYTES SCHWEINFURTHII) IN THE BUDONGO-BUGOMA LANDSCAPE OF THE ALBERTINE RIFT, UGANDA

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROMOTE COEXISTENCE BETWEEN HUMANS AND ENDANGERED EASTERN CHIMPANZEES IN WESTERN UGANDA S BUDONGO-BUGOMA LANDSCAPE BY 1 IMPROVING MONITORING OF HUMAN-CHIMPANZEE CONFLICT 2 INCREASING AWARENESS AND CAPACITY OF PRIVATE FOREST OWNERS ASSOCIATIONS TO MITIGATE HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT, INCLUDING USE OF UNPALATABLE CROPS AND LIVE FENCES AND 3 ESTABLISHING VILLAGE SAVINGS AND LOAN ASSOCIATIONS TO PROVIDE A SUSTAINABLE, COMMUNITY-DRIVEN FINANCE MECHANISM TO SUPPORT HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT MITIGATION ACTIVITIES.

title.narrative: ADDRESSING HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT INVOLVING EASTERN CHIMPANZEES (PAN TROGLODYTES SCHWEINFURTHII) IN THE BUDONGO-BUGOMA LANDSCAPE OF THE ALBERTINE RIFT, UGANDA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to promote coexistence between humans and endangered.eastern chimpanzees in western Ugandas Budongo-Bugoma landscape by: (1) improving monitoring of.human-chimpanzee conflict; (2) increasing awareness and capacity of Private Forest Owners Associations.to mitigate human-wildlife conflict, including use of unpalatable crops and live fences; and (3).establishing Village Savings and Loan Associations to provide a sustainable, community-driven finance.mechanism to support human-wildlife conflict mitigation activities.

title.narrative: RECOVERY OF EASTERN CHIMPANZEES (PAN TROGLODYTES SCHWEINFURTHII) BY DE-RISKING THEIR SUITABLE HABITATS IN THE ALBERTINE RIFT OF UGANDA

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REDUCE THE LOSS AND DEGRADATION OF CHIMPANZEE HABITAT IN THE UGANDAN ALBERTINE RIFT BY (1) RESTORING CHIMPANZEE HABITAT IN TWO FOREST RESERVES THROUGH REPLANTING AT LEAST 100 HA OF NATIVE TREE SPECIES (2) MONITORING HABITAT RECOVERY AND CHIMPANZEE USE BY COMMUNITY FOREST MONITORS (3) OPERATIONALIZING A PARTNER COORDINATION PLATFORM TO PROMOTE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE CHIMPANZEE CONSERVATION STRATEGIC ACTION PLAN (4) ENGAGING PRIVATE COMPANIES AND DEVELOPING PARTNERSHIPS TO SUPPORT CHIMP CONSERVATION (5) STRENGTHENING LOCAL CAPACITY TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION PROGRAMS THROUGH SUPPORT OF COMMUNITY ENTERPRISES, OUTREACH EDUCATION, AND CONSULTATIVE MEETINGS BETWEEN COMMUNITIES AND PROTECTED AREA AUTHORITIES AND (6) ESTABLISHING A COMMUNITY ASSOCIATION MANAGED HUMAN WILDLIFE CONFLICT RESILIENCE FUND TO COMPENSATE VICTIMS FOR NEGATIVE IMPACTS SUFFERED LOSS DUE TO CHIMPANZEES.

title.narrative: RECOVERY OF EASTERN CHIMPANZEES (PAN TROGLODYTES SCHWEINFURTHII) BY DE-RISKING THEIR SUITABLE HABITATS IN THE ALBERTINE RIFT OF UGANDA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to reduce the loss and degradation of chimpanzee habitat in the Ugandan Albertine Rift by: (1).restoring chimpanzee habitat in two forest reserves through replanting at least 100 ha of native tree species; (2) monitoring habitat.recovery and chimpanzee use by community forest monitors; (3) operationalizing a partner coordination platform to promote.implementation of the Chimpanzee Conservation Strategic Action Plan; (4) engaging private companies and developing.partnerships to support chimp conservation; (5) strengthening local capacity to implement conservation programs through support.of community enterprises, outreach education, and consultative meetings between communities and protected area authorities; and.(6) establishing a community association-managed human-wildlife conflict resilience fund to compensate victims for negative.impacts suffered loss due to chimpanzees.

title.narrative: ASSESSING THE DISTRIBUTION AND STATUS OF THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED NUBIAN FLAPSHELL TURTLE AND ENHANCING COMMUNITY CAPACITY FOR CONSERVATION IN NORTHERN UGANDA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to implement conservation activities to protect this species from.exploitation for consumption by local fishers and for sale This species was suspected to be extinct in the.wild, but a population was rediscovered along the White Nile River in southern Sudan in 2017, and again.in a remote area of northern Uganda in August 2021. Activities include: (1) conducting three, 10-day field.surveys in northern Uganda to determine its distribution and population size; (2) consulting with.stakeholders to determine best practices for conducting an awareness campaign with local communities;.(3) developing outreach materials in collaboration with government agencies; and (4) conducting.awareness campaigns and meetings with local community leaders and citizens (including youth) to assist.with ongoing community outreach and awareness for protection of this species.

title.narrative: PARASITES IN BWINDI GREAT APES: ECOLOGY, EPIDEMIOLOGY AND HEALTH IMPACTS

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CHARACTERIZE PARASITE COMMUNITIES IN GREAT APES AND DRIVING FACTORS OF A FATAL CHRONIC WASTING SYNDROME AFFECTING CRITICALLY ENDANGERED MOUNTAIN GORILLAS AND ENDANGERED EASTERN CHIMPANZEES IN BWINDI IMPENETRABLE NATIONAL PARK, UGANDA BY: (1) DETERMINING THE PARASITE DIVERSITY AND INFECTION BURDEN IN THE PARK S GREAT APES (2) DETECTING POSSIBLE RESERVOIRS OF ZOONOTIC PARASITES AFFECTING THE PARK S WILDLIFE (3) EVALUATING THE ROLE OF STRONGYLID PARASITES IN THE CLINICAL SYNDROME (4) INVESTIGATING FORCES DRIVING ZOONOTIC PARASITE INFECTIONS IN GREAT APES (5) INCREASING THE CAPACITY OF THE DISEASE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM AND (6) INCREASING LOCAL COMMUNITIES AWARENESS OF PATHOGEN TRANSMISSION RISKS.
